div.p: Belonging in WRITING TEXTUALFEATURES , TTHEMETOPIC is a very flexible tag. It has no controlled vocabulary associated with it, but can contain any information. It may enclose much more than a single word; may record central themes, side issues in a text, or objects of observation or discussion. Place tags, for instance, often appear within TTHEMETOPIC tags in accounts of travel literature, and NAME tags within accounts of biography and criticism. (Accounts of place as it operates in fiction use a TSETTINGPLACE tag.) This element applies to both theme and topic. Theme is the central idea in a text stated either directly or indirectly; topic applies to interesting subjects appearing in a work that might not aspire to the status of a "theme". The tag is useful in describing examples of genres such as educational or non-fictional texts. It has no mandatory or optional sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: <TTHEMETOPIC>forced marriage</TTHEMETOPIC> <TTHEMETOPIC> Oriental, African, pastoral, medieval, and contemporary subjects</TTHEMETOPIC> <TTHEMETOPIC> Colonial oppression</TTHEMETOPIC>

div.p: Theme differs from motif in being less tightly defined, generally informing an entire literary work. Topic can be used if a woman wrote a book about cooking, a non-fiction work on stitchery, or an educational text which uses the Napoleonic wars for its examples. A novel might equally dwell on the topic of cookery or war, or it might have military courage or womenâ€™s domestic involvement as a theme.
